The authors propose to develop several new capabilities of the novel Doppler Encoded Excitation Pattern (DEEP) microscopy technique that they have recently demonstrated for wide-field Biophotonics imaging applications. DEEP microscopy employs traveling-wave structured illumination and a sensitive high-speed single-element detector (instead of an imaging detector array) to sequentially probe the complex spatial frequencies (Fourier coefficients) of the sample using either fluoresced or scattered light. Tomographic algorithms are utilized to synthesize either an extended depth of field (DOF) 2D or, alternatively, with additional Fourier components a full 3D image. The authors have previously demonstrated that by sequentially illuminating a fluorescent sample with traveling frequency-swept sinusoidal intensity fringe patterns of diverse orientations, the DEEP technique can be used to synthesize a 2D image of a ¡­ mm3 volume that resolves diffraction limited wavelength-scale features, all in focus simultaneously, thereby providing a 1000-fold increase in DOF over a conventional microscope. Three new directions enhancing DEEP microscopy for wide-field biophotonic imaging applications will be pursued: high-speed 3D tomographic imaging multiplexed patterns created with crossed acoustooptic Bragg cells; using illumination coherence gating to extend the depth of high-resolution fluorescence imaging in strongly scattering biological tissue by utilizing broadband light; and super-resolution DEEP imaging microscopy exploiting fluorescence saturation. Each of these research directions will demonstrate a novel wide-field imaging modality for studying biological processes faster, deeper, and smaller than possible with existing techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new approach to wide-field optical microscopic imaging called Fourier-Basis Agile Structured-Illumination Sensing (F-BASIS) has been developed at the University of Colorado which enhances the depth of field of two-dimensional (2-D) images 1000-fold over conventional microscopes, enables three-dimensional (3-D) imaging, and allows 2-3 times deeper imaging in scattering media such as biological tissue.

This approach utilizes traveling-wave sinusoidal structured-light illumination patterns and a single high-speed photodetector to sample spatial Fourier components of the illuminated fluorescent or scattering sample by measuring the amplitudes and phases of sinusoidal components of the detected temporal signal, instead of the detector array and imaging lenses used in conventional microscopy.  By using a pair orthogonal acousto-optic deflectors (AODs) to generate nonredundantly spaced 2-D arrays of Doppler-encoded beams, which interfere pairwise at the sample, F-BASIS can measure over a million separable 3-D Fourier components in a single-shot on millisecond timescales and then reconstruct 3-D images of biological samples by Fourier synthesis.

The unprecedented focus-free ultra-high-speed volumetric imaging capability of F-BASIS could advance applications including studying 3-D dynamics of molecules that would otherwise migrate out of the focal plane of a conventional microscope, wide-field optical imaging within scattering biological tissue several times deeper than existing methods, mapping of cortical structures in the brain, and even 3-D tracking of propagating neuron action potentials by using voltage or ion sensitive fluorophores.

Furthermore, our small-business partner, LambdaMetrics, has obtained patent rights to and is continuing the development of the technology at the core of F-BASIS for commercialization as a novel microscopy tool for biology and health research as well as other 3-D sensing applications.
